title: Duke Treadmill Score
description: Diagnoses and prognoses suspected coronary artery disease (CAD) based on treadmill exercise test. Uses exercise time, ST deviation, and angina to predict prognosis and guide further treatment decisions.

parameters.name: exercise_time
parameters.description: Exercise time in minutes using standard Bruce protocol

parameters.name: st_deviation
parameters.description: Maximum ST change (elevation or depression) in mm in any lead except aVR

parameters.name: angina_index
parameters.description: Angina during exercise: 0 = none, 1 = non-limiting, 2 = exercise-limiting

result.name: duke_treadmill_score
result.description: Duke Treadmill Score for CAD risk stratification

ranges.interpretation: High risk for coronary artery disease with 5-year survival of 65%. Strong indication for coronary angiography. 74% of patients have 3-vessel or left main coronary disease. Consider cardiology consultation and invasive evaluation.

Intermediate risk for coronary artery disease with 5-year survival of 90%. Consider further non-invasive testing (stress imaging, coronary CT angiography) or cardiology consultation based on clinical context and risk factors.

Low risk for coronary artery disease with 5-year survival of 97%. Most patients have no coronary disease or single-vessel disease. Conservative management appropriate with medical therapy and risk factor modification.

references: Mark DB, Shaw L, Harrell FE Jr, Hlatky MA, Lee KL, Bengtson JR, et al. Prognostic value of a treadmill exercise score in outpatients with suspected coronary artery disease. N Engl J Med. 1991;325(12):849-53. doi: 10.1056/NEJM199109193251204.

Mark DB, Hlatky MA, Harrell FE Jr, Lee KL, Califf RM, Pryor DB. Exercise treadmill score for predicting prognosis in coronary artery disease. Ann Intern Med. 1987;106(6):793-800. doi: 10.7326/0003-4819-106-6-793.

Shaw LJ, Peterson ED, Shaw LK, Kesler KL, DeLong ER, Harrell FE Jr, et al. Use of a prognostic treadmill score in identifying diagnostic coronary disease subgroups. Circulation. 1998;98(16):1622-30. doi: 10.1161/01.cir.98.16.1622.
formula: Duke Treadmill Score = Exercise time (minutes) - (5 × ST deviation in mm) - (4 × angina index). Angina index: 0 = none, 1 = non-limiting, 2 = exercise-limiting. Range: -25 (highest risk) to +15 (lowest risk).
notes: Developed in 1987 and validated for prognostic assessment in suspected coronary artery disease.
Based on standard Bruce protocol exercise testing with 12-lead ECG monitoring.
Score ranges from -25 (highest risk) to +15 (lowest risk) with typical observed values.
High-risk patients (score < -11) have 74% probability of 3-vessel or left main coronary disease.
Low-risk patients (score > 5) typically have no coronary disease or single-vessel disease.
Exercise time component reflects functional capacity and cardiopulmonary fitness.
ST deviation measured as maximum change in any lead except aVR during exercise or recovery.
Angina index captures symptom severity and exercise limitation during testing.
Widely used in clinical practice for risk stratification and treatment planning.
Results should be interpreted in conjunction with clinical data and other risk factors.
May not be reliable in presence of significant valvular disease, previous cardiac surgery, or uninterpretable ECG.
1997 ACC/AHA guidelines recommend coronary angiography for high-risk patients.
Cost-effective tool for initial risk assessment in patients with suspected CAD.
Can guide decisions regarding need for further testing or invasive procedures.
